courseTitle: Determination of Molar Mass of a Volatile Liquid

pageData.titleName2: Determination of Molar Mass of a Volatile Liquid

pageData.text: In this lab, a volatile <button class='glossary-text'>organic</button> liquid is vaporized and its <button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> determined using the <button class='glossary-text'>Dumas method</button>. The ideal-gas equation is used to calculate the molar mass of the vapor at room <button class='glossary-text'>pressure</button> and the boiling point of the water bath. Its identity will be determined from a given list of organic compounds and their molar masses. Once identified, a percentage of error will be calculated for the experimental molar mass.
If the two trials in Activity 1 cannot be completed consecutively, a good stopping point is at the end of the first trial.

pageData.title: Overview Video: Determination of Molar Mass of a Volatile Liquid
Outcomes
text: Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> of an unknown volatile liquid by the <button class='glossary-text'>Dumas method</button>.
Identify the unknown molar mass by comparison to a list of known molar masses.
Calculate the percentage of error for the experimental molar mass.

pageData.text: Let's say you are sitting at a restaurant, waiting for two of your friends to join you for dinner. The server approaches your table and asks if you would like anything to drink while you wait. You order a water for yourself, a glass of soda for one friend, and a glass of orange juice for your other friend. When your friends arrive, chances are they are not going to bring a balance and find the mass of each drink to confirm you each received equal quantities. However, if someone did pull out a balance, each drink would display a different mass. But no one cares to that extent, everyone is content that they had a glass of something to enjoy.

You have just applied the <button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> concept. The individual masses of items can be different, but when dealing with molar mass the important piece is how many of those items you have, not what their respective masses are. You can relate this to cutting individual pieces of cake for several people. The pieces have different masses, but the recipients are more like molar mass: they are only concerned with how many pieces are sitting in front of them.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: Multiple slices of a chocolate cake arranged in a semi-circle.

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>Dumas method</button> is a historical method used to determine the molecular weight or <button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> of a volatile liquid. The method was originally developed by a French chemist, Jean Baptiste André Dumas, in the mid-1800s. He demonstrated a relationship between the vapor densities of <button class='glossary-text'>organic</button> compounds and their molecular weights.

Molar Mass is a physical property of a pure substance. It is expressed as g/mol. The terms formula weight and molecular weight are older terms for molar mass and are frequently interchanged. The molecular mass, however, is different. It is the mass of a given molecule, and is measured in atomic mass units.

The Dumas Method depends on vaporizing a small amount of a volatile organic substance in a known <button class='glossary-text'>volume</button> at a known <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button>. This is typically done using a flask of known volume, adding a small amount of organic substance, and then placing the flask into boiling water until all the organic substance vaporizes. If done correctly, all the air and other gases in the flask are expelled and the flask contains only the organic substance as a gas at atmospheric <button class='glossary-text'>pressure</button>. The flask is cooled and the gas condenses back into a liquid; it is then weighed.
The equation, PV = nRTn, is used to determine the molar mass of the unknown organic substance. The description of each component in the equation is given below:

text: P is and will be the atmospheric pressure during the experiment.
V is volume and will be the volume of the flask in liters.
T is temperature in Kelvin (°C + 273) of the boiling water bath.
R is the (0.0821L ·atm/mol ·K).
<button class='glossary-text'>n</button> is the number of moles and is the unknown in this experiment.

pageData.text: Knowing that moles (or <button class='glossary-text'>n</button>) can be expressed as moles = mass/<button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> (or n = m/MM), the <button class='glossary-text'>ideal gas</button> equation is easily used to determine molecular weight, as shown below:
PV = ( m / MM ) RT
MM = mRT/PV

In this activity, approximately 5 mL of a volatile liquid is placed in an Erlenmeyer flask sealed with aluminum foil. A tiny hole is made in the center of the foil to allow air and then the vaporized liquid to escape as it is heated in a water bath to boiling. All of the excess vapor escapes through the hole until the <button class='glossary-text'>pressure</button> of the vapor inside the flask equals the atmospheric pressure outside the flask.
The flask is then cooled with running water, causing the vapor in the flask to condense into a liquid. This liquid is then weighed.

pageData.question: In this investigation, why is a hole made in the aluminum foil covering the flask containing the organic substance?

options.text: to increase the pressure inside the flask
to prevent the substance from cooling too quickly
to prevent the substance from getting too hot
to allow air, excess vapor, and other gases to escape
to decrease the pressure inside the flask

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: All the excess vapor and other gases in the flask escape through the hole until the pressure of the vapor inside the flask equals the atmospheric pressure outside the flask.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Dumas method depends on vaporizing a small amount of a volatile organic substance in a known volume at a known temperature. This is typically done using a flask of known volume, adding a small amount of organic substance (in this investigation, 5 mL), and then placing the flask into boiling water until all the organic substance vaporizes. The flask is covered with foil with a pinhole opening during the heating step. If done correctly, all the air and other gases in the flask are expelled via the pinhole opening and the flask contains only the organic substance as a gas at atmospheric pressure. The flask is cooled, and the gas condenses back into a liquid; it is then weighed.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The Dumas method depends on vaporizing a small amount of a volatile organic substance in a known volume at a known temperature. This is typically done using a flask of known volume, adding a small amount of organic substance (in this investigation, 5 mL), and then placing the flask into boiling water until all the organic substance vaporizes. The flask is covered with foil with a pinhole opening during the heating step. If done correctly, all the air and other gases in the flask are expelled via the pinhole opening and the flask contains only the organic substance as a gas at atmospheric pressure. The flask is cooled, and the gas condenses back into a liquid; it is then weighed.

pageData.subTitle: Arson Scenario
pageData.text: A home was completely destroyed by fire while the occupants were away on vacation. Fire investigators suspected arson due to the rapid burning before fire personnel arrived. A large unmarked bottle containing traces of a volatile, <button class='glossary-text'>organic</button>, smelly liquid was found in a trash can behind the house. Preliminary tests revealed that the unknown liquid had a boiling point of 82° C.

Assume the role of a forensic investigator and determine the <button class='glossary-text'>molar mass</button> of this liquid by the <button class='glossary-text'>Dumas method</button> and identify it by matching it with a list of known molar masses for common accelerants. Once the liquid is identified, it may provide clues as to where the accelerant was purchased and who purchased it.

pageData.question: In this investigation, what kind of case are you trying to solve?

options.text: an arson case
a homicide case
a paternity case
a hit-and-run injury case
a burglary case

feedbackData.title: Feedback

feedbackData.title: Feedback

An unmarked bottle containing traces of a volatile, organic, smelly liquid with a boiling point of 82° C was found in a trash can behind the house. Once the liquid is identified, it may provide clues as to where the accelerant was purchased and who purchased it.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, cut two aluminum foil squares and make a flask weight ring. You will start the activity by adding five milliliters of unknown liquid sample to the flask. Then, you will heat the weighted flask in a hot water bath until the liquid in the flask has evaporated. You will record the highest temperature of the water bath, then cool the flask to room temperature. Next, you will measure the mass of the flask with the condensed vapor inside. This process will be repeated for a total of two trials. Then, you will calculate the molar mass of the condensed vapor in each trial, as well as the average molar mass. You will use this information to identify the unknown liquid. Finally, you will calculate the percent error of the experimental molar mass.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, cut two aluminum foil squares and make a flask weight ring. You will record the highest temperature of the water bath, then cool the flask to room temperature. Next, you will measure the mass of the flask with the condensed vapor inside. This process will be repeated for a total of two trials. Then, you will calculate the molar mass of the condensed vapor in each trial, as well as the average molar mass. You will use this information to identify the unknown liquid. Finally, you will calculate the percent error of the experimental molar mass.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Activity sections.

The unknown liquid and its vapors are flammable. If using a gas stove, keep the bottle away from the burner flame. If the vapor of the unknown liquid ignites as it vaporizes through the pinhole in the aluminum foil, gently blow out the flame. This is extremely rare and will only occur if a flame is close to the pinhole. Do not place a flame near the pinhole.

Keep the unknown liquid away from children and pets. It should be stored in a cool, dark place away from heat and ignition sources. Use a hot pad or oven mitt to remove the hot flask from the boiling water. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: The Dumas method was used to collect the data below about an unknown volatile accelerant. Calculate the experimental molar mass of the accelerant.Room barometric pressure = 29.93 in Hg Measured volume of the flask = 261 mL Mass of condensed vapor = 0.42 gTemperature of water bath = 100° C

options.text: 1.6 g/mol
49.3 g/mol
13.2 g/mol
493.0 g/mol
132.2 g/mol

assestmentData.question: At which point in the Dumas method is the mass of the organic substance determined?

options.text: after the substance vaporizes and condenses back into a liquid
before the substance is added to the flask
after the substance vaporizes before it has time to condense
while the substance is vaporizing in the water bath
after the condensed substance is mixed with boiling water

assestmentData.question: Sandra is vaporizing an organic substance in a flask as part of the Dumas method. When she stops heating the flask, there is still a small amount of liquid substance remaining. She allows the flask to cool and the vaporized substance to return to a liquid state. Which of the following describes the effect of not fully vaporizing the substance on Sandy’s calculations?

options.text: The calculated molar mass will be too high.
The calculated molar mass will be too low.
The calculated molar mass will not be affected.
The pressure in the flask will be too low.
The boiling point of the substance will be too low.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following assumptions can you make about the pressure in the flask when performing the Dumas method?

options.text: The pressure in the flask is equal to the atmospheric pressure.
The pressure in the flask is one half the atmospheric pressure.
The pressure in the flask is equal to the volume of the flask.
The pressure in the flask is twice the volume of the flask.
The pressure in the flask is zero.

assestmentData.question: Gabriel is using the Dumas method to determine the molar mass of a volatile organic substance. He pours a small amount of the substance into an Erlenmeyer flask, seals the top with aluminum foil, and pokes a tiny hole in the foil covering before placing the flask in a water bath. Which of the following describes the effect of the hole in the foil on Gabriel’s experiment?

options.text: Excess vapor will escape until the pressure inside and outside the flask are equal.
Most of the vapor will escape and the calculated molar mass will be too low.
Water vapor will enter the flask and the calculated molar mass will be too high.
Too little vapor will escape and the flask will break from the vapor pressure.
All the vapor will escape and will be collected in another container.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the experiment you will conduct in this investigation?

options.text: to identify an unknown liquid in an arson case using its molar mass
to identify the suspect in an arson case using the molar mass of a known substance
to determine the mass of accelerant used in an arson case
to compare the experimental molar masses of common accelerants to standard values
to determine whether an accelerant was used in an arson case

assestmentData.question: Which of the following steps should be taken if the vapor of the unknown liquid ignites as it vaporizes through the pinhole in the aluminum foil during your experiment?

options.text: Gently blow out the flame.
Pour water on the flame.
Cover the flame with more foil.
Use an oven mitt to remove the flask from the water bath.
No action is necessary.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass Erlenmeyer flask. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the Procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Using scissors and a ruler, cut two 7-cm squares of aluminum foil.

Make a weight ring for the Erlenmeyer flask as follows:
  1. Place 20 marbles in each of the two resealable bags.
  2. Leaving a corner of the resealable tab open, force all of the air out. Reseal the bag.
  3. Turn the bags sideways so that the resealable end is on the side.
  4. Pull 2 marbles away from the end for both bags, leaving two rows of 9 marbles (see Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Plastic bag arranged flat with 20 blue marbles in 2 rows inside the bag

pageData.text:
1. Fold the upper portion of the bag down until the bag is only as wide as the two rows of marbles. Keep the two marbles at the end of each bag separate.
  2. Loop a rubber band 3 times around the two marbles at the end of each bag.
  3. Lay the two bags parallel to each other, with the pair of rubber banded marbles at opposite ends (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two plastic bags with 20 blue marbles each wrapped and tied with rubber bands

pageData.text: 1. Connect the 2 bags by looping the rubber band from each bag around the opposite end of the other bag to create a circle of marbles (see Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Two plastic bags with 20 blue marbles each tied together with rubber bands into a loop

pageData.text:
• Remove all of the air out of the two resealable bags containing the marbles before sealing and tying with rubber bands.
  • When massing the flask, make sure the flask bottom is centered on the weighing pan of the balance. The edge of the flask bottom will extend out over the top half of the readout.

In Activity 1, you will set up a weighed-down Erlenmeyer flask containing unknown liquid and covered except for a pinhole opening. The flask will then be placed in a hot water bath to evaporate the liquid. You will then allow the vapor to condense at room <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button> and determine the its mass.

pages.title:
A
  Mass of Condensed Vapor (25 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Mass of Condensed Vapor (25 steps)

pageData.text: Weigh the empty 125-mL Erlenmeyer flask using the electronic balance and record this in Data table 1.
Measure approximately 5 mL of the unknown liquid with a 10-mL graduated cylinder.
Place a drop of blue food coloring in the cylinder containing the unknown liquid.
Pour the blue unknown liquid into the Erlenmeyer flask.
Rinse the graduated cylinder with tap water
Place the center of a 7-cm square of aluminum foil over the mouth of the flask and crimp the edges down over the rim. The foil should be taut across the mouth.
Secure the foil just below the rim with a rubber band.
Make a tiny hole in the center of the aluminum foil with a straight pin
Place the flask in the middle of a saucepan. Hold the flask down with one hand and add water to the saucepan until it rises to the 100-mL mark on the outside of the flask.
Remove the flask and set the pan of water on the burner of a stove.

Carefully place the weight ring of marbles over the neck of the flask without disturbing the aluminum foil covering the mouth. Adjust the marbles in the ring so they are evenly distributed on opposite sides of the flask (see Figure 4).

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Two plastic bags with 20 blue marbles each tied together with rubber bands into a loop

pageData.text: Place the flask with the weight ring in the pan of water. If the flask has a tendency to float or tip over, remove a little of the water until the flask remains upright. The water level should be between the 50-mL and 75-mL marks on the outside of the flask.
Periodically hold the thermometer in the pan to monitor the <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button>. The bulb should not touch the bottom of the pan.
Turn on the stove or hotplate burner and heat the water in the pan to boiling.
Heat the flask until the blue liquid evaporates to dryness, and continue heating for 5 additional minutes to ensure that any liquid on the upper wall of the flask vaporizes.
Record the highest temperature reached by the boiling water in °C, and convert this to Kelvin.
Turn off the burner.
Using an oven mitt or pot holder, remove the flask and place it on another pot holder or heat-resistant surface to cool for a few minutes.
Carefully remove the marble weight ring without disturbing the aluminum foil cover.
Hold the flask by the neck at a 45° angle and place it under a small stream of cold water to continue cooling it to room temperature. Do not allow the running water to touch the aluminum foil cover.
Wipe the outside of the flask dry with a paper towel.
Remove the rubber band and aluminum foil. Dry any moisture from the outside of the flask neck with a paper towel.
Measure the mass of the flask and condensed vapor and record this value in Data table 1 for Trial 1.
Rinse out the flask with tap water and thoroughly dry with paper towels.
Repeat Part A for one additional trial.

typeBefore.title:
B
Calculations (08 steps)

pageData.text: Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>volume</button> of the Erlenmeyer flask by filling it up with water.
Record this volume in milliliters in Data table 1.
Carefully measure the amount of water added using the 50-mL graduated cylinder. Keep filling the flask until the water levels with the top rim.
Find the current air <button class='glossary-text'>pressure</button> in inches of mercury by searching the Internet for “air pressure for (location)”.
Convert the air pressure from inches of mercury to the nearest 0.01 atmospheres using the following conversion, and record this value in Data table 1 for Trial 1.
_inches x ( 25.4 mm / 1 inch ) x ( 1 atm /760 mm ) = _atm
Calculate the of the condensed vapor for the two trials using the modified ideal gas equation and record this value in Data table 1 under Trial 1 and Trial 2.
Calculate the average of the two molar masses for Trial 1 and Trial 2 and record this in Data table 1.
Identify the unknown liquid by comparing the obtained molar mass value with the list of molar masses for common accelerants in Table 1.
Calculate the percentage of error for the experimental molar mass.

text: Remove marbles from the resealable bags and place them in their original storage bag
Dispose of the two plastic bags used for the weight ring.
Wash the Erlenmeyer flask and saucepan.
Rinse the graduated cylinders and dry with paper towel. Return them to the equipment kit

tableData.text: Mass of flask and condensed vapor after cooling(g)
Molar mass of unknown (MW = mRT ÷ PV)

pageData.text: Average for unknown molar mass
Identity of unknown (see Table 1)

pageData.title: Questions
text: Explain how the experimental molecular mass would have been affected if the mass of the flask had been measured with condensed vapor and residual water on the outside.
What if 10 mL of the unknown liquid were placed in the flask before heating? Evaluate how this would impact the results.
What would be the result of not having all of the liquid vaporized before cooling and measuring the mass of the flask?

You will start the activity by adding five milliliters of unknown liquid sample to the flask. Then, you will heat the weighted flask in a hot water bath until the liquid in the flask has evaporated. You will record the highest temperature of the water bath, then cool the flask to room temperature. Next, you will measure the mass of the flask with the condensed vapor inside. This process will be repeated for a total of two trials. Then, you will calculate the molar mass of the condensed vapor in each trial, as well as the average molar mass. You will use this information to identify the unknown liquid. Finally, you will calculate the percent error of the experimental molar mass.

pageData.title: Table 1.
pageData.content: Table 1. Common accelerants used by arsonists

data.title: Dumas method
data.content: A historical method used to determine the molecular weight or molar mass of a volatile liquid

data.title: Ideal gas
data.content: Incorporates several parameters that describe the gases under consideration and the interrelationships of these parameters. These parameters are pressure (p), volume (V), moles of gas (n), and its temperature (T). The Ideal Gas Law is: PV = nRT

data.title: Molar mass
data.content: A physical property of a pure substance, expressed as g/mol

data.title: n
data.content: Number of moles and is the unknown, can be expressed as moles = mass/molar mass (or n = m/MM)

data.title: Organic
data.content: Chemical compounds that generally contain carbon-hydrogen bonds

data.title: Pressure (P)
data.content: The force a gas exerts on its surroundings

data.title: Temperature (T)
data.content: A measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K)

data.title: Volume (V)
data.content: The three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or mL
